executive_summary: Credit repair service companies' contribution to the US economy will rise during the current and outlook periods, growing at a similar rate to revenue. This is emblematic of a mature industry.
industry_definition: Companies that provide services to help consumers resolve credit disputes and improve their credit scores.

positive_impact_factors: Rising interest rates have helped the industry
negative_impact_factors: Higher savings during COVID-19 hurt credit repair service providers

key_trends: Rising interest rates have helped the industry
Higher savings during COVID-19 hurt credit repair service providers

market_segmentation.segment_description: Younger people take out student and auto loans while taking out many credit cards. Since these individuals often have low incomes, this debt gives them bad credit, raising demand for the industry's services. As college enrollment has been slow, fewer young people have taken out student loans, reducing demand for credit repair services and this young consumers' revenue share.

market_segmentation.segment: Individuals between the ages of 30 and 49
market_segmentation.segment_description: These individuals are the most likely to own homes and have children, so they tend to borrow the most. Middle-aged individuals overspend often, so they run into credit issues, raising demand for credit repair services. Aggregate household debt among these consumers has surged as high inflation has made goods and services more expensive, causing middle-aged individuals' revenue share to rise during the current period.

market_segmentation.segment: Individuals between the ages of 50 and 64

market_segmentation.segment_description: Individuals over 65 have had the most time to build their credit and are the wealthiest, so they often have the highest credit scores. Since these consumers have the best credit, they don't need the industry's services often, so elderly people comprise the smallest share of revenue. Older people are the most likely to have health scares, which could ruin them financially and raise demand for credit repair services from the elderly. As demand from health and welfare funds has declined, elderly people don't have as much of a safety net to fall back on during a health scare, causing the share of revenue coming from individuals over 65 to increase during the current period.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: Demand for credit repair services depends heavily on the prevailing economic climate
demand_determinants.determinant_description: Spending on credit repair services is often countercyclical to the business cycle, as demand for their services increases when consumers find themselves under financial strain during an economic downturn. The industry also benefits from the time lag effect of consumers taking on increased debt levels during periods of economic growth when credit is more easily attainable.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: The cost of borrowing has soared as the Federal Reserve has been combatting high inflation
demand_determinants.determinant_description: The cost of borrowing has soared as the Federal Reserve has been combatting high inflation, so the share of revenue going to disputes involving these types of loans has fallen during the current period.

international_trade_points.trade_title: Credit repair service providers operate domestically
international_trade_points.trade_description: Credit repair service providers operate domestically and serve consumers in local or regional markets, so this industry does not engage in international trade.

business_locations.location_description: The Southeast region is home to big states such as Florida, Georgia, Tennessee and North Carolina, which makes the region populated. Since the area contains many people, there's a high penetration of businesses, individuals and organizations. Large numbers of people lead to lots of borrowing, so some consumers inevitably end up with bad credit. This keeps demand for credit repair service providers in the region high. Lots of providers also locate in the region because the large presence of low-income households increases the percentage of people with bad credit.

The states on the Pacific coast, specifically California, have very competitive and expensive housing markets. Expensive homes make it difficult for consumers to afford their mortgages, so they often face financial trouble. These individuals often turn to credit repair service providers for help with their mortgage debt, so many establishments exist in the Western part of the country.

The Mid-Atlantic region includes big and dense metropolitan regions such as New York, Philadelphia and Washington DC. Since this region is very urban, lots of borrowing takes place because of the significant levels of economic activity. Lots of borrowing leads to credit disputes, which raises demand for the industry's services.

regulations_points.regulation_description: The Credit Repair Organizations Act (CROA) is a law created in 1996 as Title IV of the broader Consumer Credit Protection Act. The act prohibits fraud by credit repair organizations (CROs). CROs are prohibited from collecting any advance fees before services are rendered.

In October 2008, the FTC, in accordance with 22 states, announced Operation Clean Sweep, a plan to target 33 specific credit repair service operations for noncompliance with the CROA as a response to thousands of consumer complaints across the United States. The FTC charged these institutions with falsely claiming they could remove negative credit information from consumer reports, even if it was accurate.

To ensure that COVID-19 didn't spread, governments forced companies to enforce social distancing and mask-wearing laws. Most credit repair service providers worked from home during the pandemic, but employees that still came to the office had to adhere to these regulations. Some establishments also required their employees to receive the COVID-19 vaccine when it became available.

barriers_points.barrier_description: The industry has high revenue volatility.

factors_decreased_barrier: The industry has low capital intensity level.
The industry has low concentration level.

basis_points.basis_title: Service quality and reputation for success are key competitive factors
basis_points.basis_description: Companies compete on service quality and their reputation for success, regardless of segment.

basis_points.basis_title: Price competition due to large number of companies
basis_points.basis_description: The large number of companies operating in the industry yields some price competition.

basis_points.basis_title: Demonstrable past successes and word-of-mouth important
basis_points.basis_description: Key factors include demonstrable past successes in removing negative credit items and word-of-mouth recommendations from other clients.

basis_points.basis_title: Client satisfaction and positive recommendations help succeed
basis_points.basis_description: Companies that have a high level of client satisfaction and generate positive recommendations are better able to succeed.

basis_points.basis_title: Accreditations from organizations like Better Business Bureau
basis_points.basis_description: Players also compete based on accreditations from outside organizations, such as the Better Business Bureau.

concentration_points.concentration_title: Low start-up costs lead to many companies
concentration_points.concentration_description: Start-up costs for this industry are very low, as the only physical capital entrants need to invest in computers, office space and a few workers. These low initial costs cause many individuals to become credit repair service providers, increasing the number of companies.

concentration_points.concentration_title: Small players have good local reputations
concentration_points.concentration_description: Many small credit repair service companies include nonemployers that sell their services to customers in one specific region. Since these small players have operated for a long time, they've established a good reputation with individuals in their local community.

cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Profit declined during COVID-19 despite revenue being negatively correlated with the performance of the US economy. While economic conditions were bad during the pandemic, savings soared in 2020 because the government provided financial assistance. High savings led to increased demand for credit repair services, boosting industry revenue.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Wages Surge Because Workers Have Significant Negotiating Power
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Workers in this industry are highly skilled, as it's necessary to have some knowledge of finance to help consumers repair their credit and negotiate with lenders. As inflation has soared, employees have threatened to move to other industries if companies don't increase their pay. These workers can move to other companies since they're highly skilled, so employers have relented and raised their wages, causing wages' revenue share to surge during the current period.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Physical Purchases Have Increasingly Become Less Important
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: As credit repair services are increasingly done online, the need for office supplies has fallen, causing purchases' revenue share to decline during the current period.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: MISCELLANEOUS COSTS HAVE BECOME LESS POTENT
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Credit repair service workers have traveled far less often since COVID-19, so miscellaneous costs' revenue share has declined during COVID-19.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Credit repair service providers exhibit a low level of capital intensity. For every $1.00 spent on labor, the average company is expected to invest $0.03 in capital equipment in 2023. The nature of credit repair services depends more heavily on the knowledge, skill level and customer service capabilities of employees. As the industry has migrated online, more labor is needed to develop online systems that enable consumers to track the progress of their cases. The capital and equipment that most companies need are often limited to computers, software and technology used to assist in payment collections, data processing and other administrative duties.

volatility_points.volatility_description: The industry's performance is countercyclical to that of the US economy. When unemployment is high, more people have trouble paying off debt, so they seek credit repair services. When the economy is strong, more individuals can pay these bills.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Interest Rates Make Revenue Growth More Uncertain
volatility_points.volatility_description: As interest rates rise, more consumers have trouble paying their bills, hurting credit scores and raising demand for the industry's services. Individuals' financial situations improve when interest rates are low, aiding credit repair service providers. Interest rates have fluctuated recently, as the Federal Reserve reduced the cost of borrowing significantly during the pandemic but increased them during the recovery to combat high inflation. Shifting interest rates have increased revenue volatility.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Consumers Are More Financially Stable When They Save More
volatility_points.volatility_description: When more households save, they can pay off debt more quickly. This reduces demand for credit repair services. If savings are low, consumers often ruin their credit if they face unexpected expenses, increasing the need for the industry's services. The savings rate has shifted significantly during the current period because of government aid, economic confidence and other factors, raising revenue volatility.

technological_change_points.technological_change_description: The Credit Repair Services industry contends with some degree of technological disruption. Credit reporting agencies have made disputing credit reports far easier through online forms and other communication mediums. Consumers seeking to repair their credit have become more likely to forgo credit repair services in favor of contacting the credit bureaus on their own. The ease with which one can repair their credit varies greatly, so credit repair services still provide a worthwhile value-add to consumers with more complex credit problems.

Technological change within the Credit Repair Services industry has been moderate during the current period. The number of companies shifting operations online has continued to grow. The increased prevalence of automation within the industry has removed the need for extraneous labor. Many companies have implemented new software and other equipment to help speed data processing, credit analysis and other administrative duties. Technological change within the industry is expected to rise during the outlook period as more companies incorporate digital processes and internet-based client communication into their business model.

FAQs.question: How do you communicate the value of your company's services?
FAQs.answer: Credit repair service providers have struggled to communicate value-add to clients as most of their work can be done independently online.

FAQs.question: How has the shift toward conducting business online affected demand for your services?
FAQs.answer: The shift toward online services has negatively impacted revenue for the industry. To cope, many credit repair services are shifting to digital-only platforms.

FAQs.question: What is NACSO?
FAQs.answer: NACSO was founded in 2007 and provides certification to credit repair service providers. Companies can receive the NACSO 'Standards of Excellence' seal to demonstrate that they offer excellent credit repair services and never engage in fraud.

FAQs.question: How did the COVID-19 pandemic affect the industry?
FAQs.answer: The pandemic caused Congress to pass the Paycheck Protection Program (PPP), which enabled companies to receive forgivable loans from the federal government to pay for lost wages and rents because of social distancing regulations and quarantines. While credit repair companies could operate virtually, some players took advantage of PPP loans, as they were negatively affected by the social distancing rules and the significant drop in spending that resulted from the pandemic.

FAQs.question: What is your company doing to reduce costs?
FAQs.answer: The highest cost for credit repair companies is wages. Credit repair services are cutting wage costs by incorporating automation and digital customer interfaces into their business models.

FAQs.question: Are your operations spread across the country or concentrated in certain locations?
FAQs.answer: Credit repair services follow the general distribution of the population. They are often located in urban areas where consumers require greater amounts of credit to live and conduct business.

FAQs.question: How have you taken advantage of rising online and mobile penetration?
FAQs.answer: Free online credit repair services have stolen business from in-person franchise brokers and consultants. Many credit repair services have adapted by creating digital customer interfaces. This has done little to help revenue since online consultation is often free.

FAQs.question: How do you use technology to build your client network?
FAQs.answer: Credit repair service providers use digital advertising to acquire new customers, especially since many of the industry's customers are below the age of 30.

FAQs.question: How does your company maintain compliance standards?
FAQs.answer: There are many regulations regarding payment to credit repair services and what information can be removed from a customer's credit report. Companies must adhere to standards dictated by the Federal Trade Commission (FTC).

FAQs.question: Does your company require assistance in navigating the regulatory landscape?
FAQs.answer: The FTC has grown increasingly scrupulous in its interactions with credit repair services, increasing the importance of properly navigating the regulatory environment.

FAQs.question: What methods have you adopted to improve cash flow?
FAQs.answer: Companies in the industry have diversified their range of services to include strategy, legal, and operational consulting services for financially-distressed clients.

FAQs.question: Has your company considered merger opportunities?
FAQs.answer: Merger activity has been light in recent years, as many companies have displayed falling revenue and profit, making them less attractive for acquisition.

FAQs.question: What is your prior success rate with repair work?
FAQs.answer: Being able to point to prior successes is advantageous in winning new business and developing a strong reputation.

FAQs.question: Are you known for your reliability and performance?
FAQs.answer: A reputation for success and reliability is advantageous in this industry, especially since most companies are small and lack extensive marketing capacity.

FAQs.question: How do you make sure your prices are attractive to customers?
FAQs.answer: Competitive pricing strategies.

FAQs.question: How do you balance price rates to stimulate demand?
FAQs.answer: Price adjustments based on market conditions.

FAQs.question: How important is membership in an industry organization?
FAQs.answer: Past controversy over unscrupulous practices by some players has made membership in a recognized industry body important in establishing legitimacy.

FAQs.question: How does your business account for changes in the personal savings rate?
FAQs.answer: The personal savings rate is the percentage of personal discretionary income that is saved during a given period. An increase in the personal savings rate leads to lower demand for credit repair services because savings increase the ability of consumers to repay debt.

FAQs.question: How do changing levels of aggregate household debt affect your business?
FAQs.answer: Aggregate household debt represents all outstanding credit market debt held by consumers. When aggregate household debt rises, consumers are more confident about servicing those debts, negatively affecting the industry.

FAQs.question: How do you protect your business against fluctuations in debt?
FAQs.answer: Diversification of services and client base.
